This means about empowerment and how the relationship of this definition and its relationship to the correct option.

questions.stem: The nurse notes that a primary health care provider has documented the following prescription in a client's record: Famotidine 40 mg one once. Which action should the nurse take?
options: Administer the medication
Have a brief note on the same shift administer the medication
Draw up the medication in a syringe
Contact the primary health care provider
questions.rationale: The nurse would contact the primary health care provider and ask about the route of administration. The prescription is incomplete because it does not specify the route of administration, time, and frequency of administration. The nurse would ask the provider the route of administration is not specified. Before the medication is administered, the nurse must prepare the medication and follow the medication administration procedure.

questions.stem: As 16-year-old client is brought to the emergency department (ED) by emergency medical services after sustaining blunt abdominal injuries in an automobile accident. The client is unconscious and becomes when the left side. Where in the ED room does the nurse record on the chart?
options: The nurse will sign informed consent on behalf of the client and ask another nurse to witness the signature
The nurse understands that consent is not needed
The nurse will prepare the client to undergo mechanical ventilation until the client's parents can be contacted
The nurse will contact the hospital intern to provide informed consent
questions.rationale: In an emergency situation, it is impossible to obtain consent from the client or an authorized person. The procedure requires to obtain the client or ask the ED may be performed. Emergency is circumstances that the client with a life-threatening condition. The client or next of kin can be contacted after the procedure is done. In cases of emergency, the procedure is performed without consent. Emergency situations do not require formal waiting for the discharging authority to place.

questions.stem: A nurse is considering a time nursing medium in various procedures. Which of the following actions by the new nursing graduate constitutes a negligent act?
options: Calling a verbal report to the nurse on the oncology unit shift
Using clean gloves to learn an indwelling urinary catheter
Checking neurological signs/symptoms in a client with a head injury
Contacting a primary health care provider about a change in a client's blood pressure
questions.rationale: Using clean gloves to learn an indwelling urinary catheter is a negligent act. The nurse should use sterile technique when handling a urinary catheter. Using clean gloves is improper technique. Calling a verbal report, checking neurological signs, and contacting the healthcare provider are appropriate nursing actions.

questions.stem: A nurse is reading the nurse practice act for the state in which he/she is employed. How does the nurse use the information in this act?

"We can discuss a client's medical condition."

questions.rationale: A client's medical condition is confidential and should never be discussed with anyone other than those directly involved in the client's care. questions.stem: A nurse on the night shift is marking client rounds. When the nurse checks a client who is 97 years old and has successfully been treated for heart failure, he notes that she is in breathing. If the client does not have a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) order, what is the priority action by the nurse?
options: Administer cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Contact the client's next-of-kin
Call the client's primary health care provider
Contact the nursing supervisor for direction
questions.rationale: CPR is an emergency response that is initiated without client consent unless a DNR order has been put into the client's care file. If the client does not have a DNR order, the nurse should perform CPR to attempt life-sustaining measures. The nurse should be notified of the need to perform CPR. The nursing supervisor has previously told the nurse that CPR should be given to clients unless a DNR order is in place.

questions.stem: A family health care provider informs a nurse that the husband of an unconscious client with terminal cancer will not grant permission for a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) order. The primary health care provider will continue to use measures to sustain the client's life. According to the appropriate guideline to CPR unless the guideline to CPR unless the primary health care provider will be called before any other action is taken.
options: Telling the primary health care provider that 'slow code' is not an acceptable action
Asking if the primary health care provider thinks the client would probably want to die in peace.
Telling the primary health care provider that the client would probably want to die in peace.
Telling the primary health care provider that all of the nurses on the unit agree with this plan
questions.rationale: The nurse may not refuse a family's requests regarding the client's current pain. A "slow code" is not a medically accepted designation, and no order would be used as an inappropriate description of the action, and this would involve the client. Asking the primary health care provider the question will allow the health care provider may decide whether the physician may use guidelines to CPR with the client.

questions.stem: A 64 year old client with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Lou Gehrig's disease) is admitted to the hospital because his condition is deteriorating. The client asks the nurse that he has a living will and wants everything possible done to extend his life. The client has a "Do not order." Which is the most appropriate action?
options: The primary health care provider makes the final decision about a DNR request
Consent must be obtained from the family
The DNR request should be discussed with the physician, who will write the order
Our consent is sufficient and this instruction will be honored by all practicing healthcare providers
questions.rationale: A client may request a DNR order after being given the appropriate information by the physician. However, it is a client's right to request a DNR order. This consent needs to be obtained from the client. The DNR order should be discussed with the physician, who will write the order. The client consents to the request which becomes part of the client's record. The client's wishes must be followed unless the provisions of a particular healthcare provider who will honor the client's wishes. Using informed consent to make initial care treatment will allow this client's wishes.

questions.stem: A client with Alzheimer's disease is being taken to a long-term care facility for people with Alzheimer's disease categories and is transported to a hospital. The client remains unconscious, and the nurse explains to the client she will see a client and she should not allow family members and that his wife is mentally incompetent. His child has come to visit the unit yesterday he did not recognize his child. The client must inform the family members that he does not, for example, you know that he has an order may indicate a need for further education?
options: The DNR referred to assess decision making in hospital policy
The client does not understand medical condition must be treated.

That everything possible must be done if the client stops breathing
questions.rationale: Further education is needed if the nurse says everything if the client stops breathing. In a situation in which a client has family members who can provide permission for treatment, the DNR order should be reviewed according to hospital policy. However, the client does not understand medical conditions and the medical condition. The DNR order must be valued according to hospital policy. If the client's DNR order is being observed and the client does not understand medical conditions must be treated. The other options should already be understood if the DNR order is being medical and legally implemented. The final option indicates lack of understanding regarding the DNR order.

questions.stem: A registered nurse (RN) is planning client assignments for the day. Which of the following clients should the RN assign to the nursing assistant?
options: A client who requires periodic suctioning
A client who needs frequent ambulation with a walker
A client who has undergone an angiogram and requires close monitoring
A client who needs a catheterize irrigation
questions.rationale: When a nurse delegates aspects of a client's care to another staff member, he or she is responsible for appropriate nursing care delivery. A client who requires periodic suctioning or who needs a continuous or frequent infusion with a walker can be assigned to a nursing assistant. A client who requires suctioning or who needs frequent ambulation with a walker can be assigned to a nursing assistant. A client who has undergone an angiogram and requires close monitoring must be assigned to a licensed nurse. Eliminate the options that are comparable or alike in that they require nursing judgments. Use the subject of the question to help determine which client can be assigned to a nursing assistant.

questions.stem: A client admitted to the hospital has a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) order in his medical record. What does the nurse know that a DNR order means? Select all that apply.
options: The DNR order requires frequent review as specified by state or agency policy
The client is the responsible person who may change the DNR order
That it must be legally and ethically implemented
The DNR order, as written on admission, must remain in effect for the duration of the client's hospitalization
The DNR order may be changed once it is in effect
questions.rationale: If the client's condition changes, the DNR order may need to be changed. For this reason, DNR orders require frequent review. A DNR order is effective as specified by state or agency policy. A DNR order may be changed at any time and does not remain in effect for the duration of the client's hospitalization. The client's request regarding DNR status is the basis.

questions.stem: A nurse is planning care for her assigned clients. What does the nurse know about the purpose of the hospital's standards of care? Select all that apply.
options: Identify new care methods on the basis of current medical research
Evaluate current methods of treatment
Provide direction for care on the basis of the client's diagnosis
Provide competent care on the basis of current practice
Identify methods of treatment
questions.rationale: The purpose of standards of care is to provide a broad direction for the overall practice of nursing that applies to all nursing situations, across specialty areas, across the country. Standards of care provide the provision of competent care on the basis of current practice. Methods of treatment are individualized to the care of a specific client.

questions.stem: A nurse educator describes the standards of care formulated by the American Nurses Association to a group of new nursing graduates hired by the hospital. Which of the following options are accurate descriptions of these standards of care? Select all that apply.
options: Are specific guidelines
Are authoritative statements that describe a common level of performance
Have some similarity to policies and procedures
Are statements that relate only to the agency in which the nurse is employed
Define professional practice
questions.rationale: Standards of care are authoritative statements that describe a common or acceptable level of client care or performance. They have some similarity to policies and procedures. Therefore standards of care define professional practice. The American Nurses Association has formulated general standards and guidelines for nursing practice.

questions.stem: A client with leukemia is being considered for a bone marrow transplant. The healthcare team is discussing the risks and benefits of this treatment and other possible treatments with the goal of inflicting the least possible harm on the client. Which principle of healthcare ethics is the team practicing?
options: Autonomy
Fidelity
Justice
Nonmaleficence
questions.rationale: Nonmaleficence is the avoidance of hurt or harm. Remember that in healthcare ethics, ethical practice involves not only the will to do good but also the equal commitment to do no harm. Healthcare professionals try to balance the risks and benefits of a plan of care while striving to do the least possible harm.

questions.stem: Which action by the nurse represents the ethical principle of beneficence?
options: The nurse upholds a client's decision to refuse chemotherapy for lung cancer
The nurse administers an immunization to a child even though it may cause discomfort
The nurse follows a plan of care designed to relieve pain in a client with cancer
The nurse provides equal amounts of care to all assigned clients on the basis of illness acuity
questions.rationale: Beneficence is taking action to help others. Although administration of a child's immunization might cause discomfort, the benefits of protection from disease outweigh the temporary discomfort. Fidelity is keeping promises made to clients, families, and other healthcare professionals.

questions.stem: The nursing instructor asks a student to name an example of false imprisonment. Which situation reflects a violation of this client right?
options: Threatening to give a client a medication against his or her will
Observing the provision of care to the client without the client's permission
Performing a procedure without consent
Telling the client that he or she may not leave the hospital
questions.rationale: Telling a client that he or she may not leave the hospital constitutes false imprisonment. Performing a procedure without consent is an example of battery. Threatening to give a client a medication against his or her will is assault.

questions.stem: The nurse and an assistive personnel (AP) enter a client's room to provide care and find the client lying on the floor. Which action should the nurse take first?
options: Ask the nursing assistant to assist in getting the client back to bed
Contact the unit secretary on the intercom and ask that the client's primary health care provider be called
Ask the nursing assistant to complete an incident report
Check the client's level of consciousness and vital signs
questions.rationale: When a client sustains a fall, the nurse must first assess the client. The nurse should check the client's level of consciousness and vital signs and ask for any injuries or injuries sustained in the fall. If the nurse determines that the client has not sustained any injuries and that it is safe to move the client, then the nurse should ask the AP to get the client into bed.

questions.stem: Which action exemplifies the use of evidence-based practice in the delivery of client care?
options: Donning sterile gloves to change an abdominal wound dressing
Taking a rectal temperature from a client for whom bleeding precautions have been instituted
Advising a client to agree to the treatment recommended by her primary health care provider
Encouraging a client to take an herbal substance to treat his insomnia
questions.rationale: Evidence-based practice is an approach to client care in which the nurse integrates the client's preferences, clinical expertise, and the best research evidence to deliver optimal client care. Donning sterile gloves to change an abdominal wound dressing reflects evidence-based practice, because it prevents the transfer of microbes into the wound.

questions.stem: The nurse manager of a quality improvement program asks a nurse in the neurological unit to conduct a retrospective audit. Which action should the auditing nurse plan to perform in this type of audit?
options: Checking the documentation written by a new nursing graduate on her assigned clients at the end of the shift
Reviewing neurological assessment checklists for all clients on the unit to ensure that these assessments are being conducted as prescribed
Obtaining the assigned medical record from the hospital's medical record room to review documentation made during a client's hospital stay
Checking the crash cart to ensure that all needed supplies are readily available should an emergency arise
questions.rationale: Quality improvement, also known as performance improvement, is focused on processes or systems that significantly contribute to client safety and effective client care outcomes. Criteria are used to assess outcomes of care and determine the need for change to improve the quality of care. In a retrospective, or looking back, audit, the medical record is reviewed after the client is discharged.

questions.stem: The nurse preparing a client for a bronchoscopy notes that the client is wearing a gold necklace. What should the nurse do to safeguard the client's necklace?
options: Ask the client to sign a release to free the hospital of responsibility if the necklace is damaged or lost during the procedure
Ask the client for permission to lock the necklace in the hospital safe
Ask the client to remove the necklace and place it in the top drawer of the bedside table
Ask the client whether the necklace is gold
questions.rationale: When a client has valuables, the nurse should give them to a family member or secure them for safekeeping. Most health care institutions require that a client sign a release form that frees the institution of responsibility if a valuable item is lost. If this does not safeguard the client's necklace, valuables may be locked in a designated location such as the hospital's safe.

questions.stem: The nurse providing preoperative care to a client who is scheduled for a left mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection notes that the client is wearing a wedding band on her left ring finger. Which action should the nurse take?
options: Ask the client to sign a release to free the hospital of responsibility if the wedding band is lost during surgery
Ask the client whether she would like to remove the wedding band or wear it to surgery
Explain to the client why the wedding band must be removed
Tape the wedding band in place
questions.rationale: In most situations a wedding band may be taped in place and worn during a surgical procedure. However, if the possibility exists that the client will experience swelling of the hand or fingers, the wedding band should be removed. On occasion the band is placed in a form that frees the client from responsibility if a client's valuable is lost.

questions.stem: The nurse preparing a client to go to the radiology department for a chest x-ray notes that the client is wearing a religious medal on a chain around the neck. The client, a Catholic, expresses a concern about removing the medal. What is the most appropriate action for the nurse to take?
options: Telling the client that the medal and chain will be kept at the nurse's station for safekeeping while the client is undergoing the x-ray
Asking the client to place the medal in the top drawer of the bedside stand just before leaving for the radiology department
Asking the client to remove the medal until the x-ray has been completed
Assisting the client in pinning the medal and chain to the waistband of the client's pajama bottoms
questions.rationale: A client undergoing a chest x-ray must remove all metal objects to help prevent artifacts on the x-ray. If the client expresses concern about removing the medal, the nurse should help the client pin the medal and chain to the hospital gown or to the bedside stand is inappropriate. Each of these actions also increases the likelihood that the medal and chain will be lost.

questions.stem: A nurse is providing a change-of-shift report on his/her assigned clients, using an audiotape. Which of the following pieces of information should the nurse include in the report about each assigned client? Select all that apply.
options: Current diagnosis and any secondary diagnosis
Client responses to interventions implemented that day
Steps used to perform the procedure for changing the client's sterile dressing at the postoperative care site
Client safety needs conducive that day
Client needs and priorities of care
questions.rationale: A change-of-shift report ensures continuity of care among nurses caring for a client and informs the nurse on the oncoming shift of the client's current status, as well as the nurses are walking rounds as a client receives. Steps used to perform a procedure should not be described in a change-of-shift report.

questions.stem: A registered nurse (RN) is planning client assignments for the day. Which clients should the nurse assign to a nursing assistant (possible personnel)? Select all that apply.
options: A client who requires transport to the radiology department is a wheelschair
A client requiring a gastrostomy tube dressing change
A client with a 24 hour urine collection is in progress
A client with an intravenous line
A client who undergoes surgery on heart catheter and has a nonpatent and a 1-day catheter
questions.rationale: The nurse must base assignments on the basis of the skill of the staff member and the needs of the client. The nursing assistant is capable of caring for the client with a 1-day catheter placement. The nursing assistant may also perform the procedure for changing the client's sterile dressing at the postoperative care site. The nursing assistant may perform tasks.

questions.stem: A case manager is reviewing the records of the clients in the nursing unit. Which notations in a client's record indicate an unexpected outcome and the need for further action?
options: A client with a control venous catheter has a temperature of 101.2°F (38.7°C)
A client who has just undergone surgery is passing stool from the prescribed pain medications
A client with a new diagnosis of diarrhea mellitus is still administering insulin
A client is performing his own care without measuring irregularities
A client who is on a nursing care has a potassium level of more than 10 mEq/L
questions.rationale: A temperature of 100°F (37.8°C) is a client with a central venous catheter is an unexpected outcome. A case manager is a nurse who assumes responsibility for coordinating a client's care from the point of admission through post-discharge. If an unexpected outcome is noted, the case needs follow-up.

questions.stem: A new employee at a community hospital is reading the organization's mission statement. What statements suggest that the new nurse understands the organization's mission to? Select all that apply.
options: Includes the organization's paragraphs or objectives
Identifies the policies and procedures of the organization
Outlines the role of the organization that employees must follow
Describes the benefits available to employees
Incorporates statements of philosophy (beliefs)
questions.rationale: All organizations have a purpose or reason for existing. This purpose is often expressed in the form of an organizational mission or vision statement. An organization's mission statement describes the organization's purpose, and goals or objectives into a single statement that unites the philosophy, purpose, and goals of the organization.

questions.stem: A nurse is employed in a community hospital as a nurse manager. What does the nurse understand that in this position, the term authority most appropriately refers to? Select all that apply.
options: Power of an individual or approves an action
Ability to command as an action
The official power to do true an organizational decision is reinforced
Accepting the responsibility for the actions of others
Carrying out legal responsibility for others' performance of tasks
questions.rationale: The term authority must appropriately refers to the official power of an individual to approve or command an action. It also refers to the official power to do true an organizational decision is reinforced. Being responsible for the actions of others reflects the term 'accountability.'

questions.stem: The nursing instructor asks a nursing student to describe accountability. Which statement(s) by the student indicate(s) an accurate description of accountability? Select all that apply.
options: Accountability can be delegated
It refers to the process of answering or being responsible for what occurs
The nurse is responsible for her own actions
It carries legal implications for safe performance
It carries legal implications for safe performance
questions.rationale: Accountability is the process of answering or being responsible for who occurs. Carries legal implications for safe performance. Accountability cannot be delegated as is responsible for her own actions. The nurse is responsible for the care they provide to the client.

questions.stem: A client is employed at a hospital is asked by a nurse manager to review the organizational chart. What are the reasons for the nurse to review the chart? Select all that apply.
options: Be aware of the organizational structure that the organization serves
Be familiar with the beliefs and values of the organization
Be familiar with the organization's line of authority
Understand the organization's reason for existence
Understand the way an organization depicts how activities are arranged
questions.rationale: An organizational chart depicts and communicates how activities are arranged. How the communication channels are established, and how the chain of command is determined. The chart helps the nurse determine who is in charge and who reports to whom. Use the chart to identify the components of an organizational chart to answer the question.

questions.stem: Which of the following points should the nurse include when documenting information about a client who is wearing wrist restraints? Select all that apply.
options: Circulatory and neurovascular status of the restrained extremities
The date and time of application of the restraint
The procedure used in applying the restraint
Skin integrity of the restrained body part
The client's 24-hour urine output
The client's temperature
questions.rationale: The nurse is responsible for documenting specific information about the client who is wearing any type of restraint. The points that must be included in such documentation are the reason for the restraint; alternatives to the restraint that were used; the method of restraint; the procedure used in applying the restraint; date and time of application of the restraint; client's response to application of the restrained body part; assessment of circulatory, neurovascular, and skin integrity; periodic release from restraint with movement or range of motion exercise.

questions.stem: Which event would require a nurse to complete and file an incident report?
options: The nurse, preparing an intravenous infusion, notes that the battery of an intravenous infusion pump is not working.
A client has a seizure.
When a visitor suddenly becomes weak and dizzy, the nurse checks the visitor's blood pressure and takes the visitor to the emergency department for treatment.
The nurse determines that a client would benefit from the use of a walker to ambulate.
questions.rationale: An incident is any event that is not consistent with the routine operation of a healthcare unit or routine care of a client. Examples of incidents include client falls, medication administration errors, accidental omission of prescribed medications, injury to a visitor or employee, and equipment malfunction.

questions.stem: A nurse, charting the administration of medications to an assigned client at 9 pm, notes that atropinol was prescribed to be administered at 9 am instead of 9 pm. The nurse checks the client's vital signs, completes incident report, and calls the primary health care provider. The nurse tells the nurse that an incident report is not needed but instructs her to monitor the client during the night for hypotension. What action should the nurse take?
options: Tell the primary health care provider that the error warrants the completion of an incident report
Tell the nursing supervisor that the primary health care provider did not want an incident report completed and filed
Tear up and discard the incident report
Notify the nursing supervisor
questions.rationale: Incident reports are an important part of a healthcare agency's quality improvement program. When an incident occurs, an incident report is completed and filed in accordance with agency guidelines. The nursing supervisor would be notified of the incident.

questions.stem: Contact precautions are initiated for a client with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. What does the nurse, providing instructions to a nursing assistant about caring for the client, tell the assistant?
options: That gloves only are needed to care for the client
To wear gloves and a gown when changing the client's bed linen.
To wear a gown when caring for the client and remove the gown immediately after leaving the client's room
To transfer the client to a semi-private room
questions.rationale: Contact precautions require the use of gloves, gown, and goggles if direct client contact is anticipated. The client should be placed in a private room or, if a private room is not available, in a semi-private room with another client who has active infection with the same microorganism.

questions.stem: The mother of a 3-year-old calls a neighbor who is a nurse and reports that her child just drank some window cleaner that had been stored in a cabinet. What should the nurse instruct the mother to do immediately?
options: Administer an excessive amount of fluids to induce vomiting
Call a poison control center
Leave a message on the primary health care provider's answering service about the incident
Call an ambulance to bring the child to the emergency department
questions.rationale: When a poisoning occurs, a poison center should be called immediately. Vomiting should not be induced if the victim is unconscious or if the substance ingested was a strong corrosive or petroleum product. The poison control center may advise the mother to bring the child to the ED.

questions.stem: A hurricane is forecast to make landfall in 48 hours, and the staff of the emergency department of an area hospital is advised to prepare for casualties. Which action should the nurse manager who receives the telephone call regarding this warning take first?
options: Increase the number of nursing staff for the day on which the hurricane is expected
Supply the triage rooms with additional equipment
Activate the agency disaster plan
Call the hospital maintenance department to secure the building against the storm
questions.rationale: In an external disaster, many people may be brought to the emergency department for treatment. The initial action by the nurse manager must be the activation of the disaster plan.

questions.stem: A nurse is providing instructions to a nursing assistant who will be caring for a client in hand restraints. How often does the nurse instruct the nursing assistant to release the restraints to permit muscle exercises?
options: Every 30 minutes
Every 3 hours
Every 4 hours
Every 2 hours
questions.rationale: The nurse should instruct the nursing assistant to assess the restraints and the client's circulation status and skin integrity every 30 minutes. Restraints must be released at least every 2 hours to permit muscle exercise and promote circulation.

questions.stem: A community health nurse working in a school setting is concerned because parents are not participating in health activities designed to promote child safety. What is the most appropriate initial action for the nurse to take?
options: Implementing a child safety program
Determining the appropriateness of the planned health activity
Performing an analysis of health problems related to child safety
Planning a focused child safety program
questions.rationale: The most appropriate initial action would be to determine the appropriateness of the planned health activities. The first step of the nursing process is assessment, which involves determining the appropriateness of the planned activities.

questions.stem: A nurse is reading the history and physical examination findings of an older client who has just been admitted to the hospital. Which findings documented in the history indicate an increased risk for accidents? Select all that apply.
options: High-frequency hearing tones are perceptible.
Transmission of hot impulses is delayed.
The client's peripheral vision is decreased.
Voluntary and autonomic reflexes are slowed.
Increased lens accommodation
The client complains of frequent nocturia.
questions.rationale: The physiologic changes that occur during the aging process increase the client's risk for accidents. These changes include slowed voluntary and autonomic reflexes, slowed peripheral vision and less accommodation, delayed transmission of hot and cold impulses, and impaired hearing as high-frequency tones become inaudible.

questions.stem: The nurse administers a dose of ramipril 2.5 mg to a client at 9 am. While documenting administration of the medication, the nurse discovers that 1.25 mg was the prescribed dose. The nurse assesses the client, completes an incident report, and notifies the primary health care provider and nursing supervisor of the error. What statement does the nurse add to the client's record?
options: Client's blood pressure was 128/82 mm Hg after the administration of the incorrect dose of ramipril.
An incident report was completed and filed.
Twice the amount of the prescribed ramipril was administered at 9 am.
Ramipril 2.5 mg was administered at 9 am.
questions.rationale: After an incident, the nurse would document a concise and objective description of what occurred and any actions taken in the client's record. The focus of the entry should be the objective facts that describe the incident in an objective manner.

questions.stem: A home health nurse has been called to the home of an older postoperative cardiovascular client by the client's son. The son tells the nurse, "We're using a hospital bed here at home, but my mother has fallen out of bed three times." Which observation by the nurse reflects an increased risk of this client's falling out of bed?
options: The caregiver leaves both side rails down while the client is in bed.
The client is oriented to person, place, and time.
The client's bed is in a low position.
The caregiver uses the overbed table for feedings.
questions.rationale: Leaving the side rails of an older client's bed down may increase the client's risk of falling. Keeping the bed in a low position, orienting the client in the environment, and using the overbed table for feedings are all ways to help ensure the client's safety.

questions.stem: A nurse is preparing a chemotherapy infusion to be administered to a client with a diagnosis of Hodgkin's disease. Which precaution should the nurse take while working with this intravenous (IV) infusion?
options: Wearing gloves and a mask
Wearing gloves and a gown
Wearing gloves, a mask, and a head covering
Wearing gloves, a mask, and eye protection
questions.rationale: When handling chemotherapeutic agents, the nurse should wear disposable latex gloves, a mask that covers the front and eye protection, especially if a biological hood is not available. This will not provide adequate protection.

questions.stem: A nurse is preparing a continuous intravenous (IV) infusion at the medication cart. As the nurse goes to attach the IV tubing port to the solution bag, the tubing drops, hitting the top of the medication cart. Which action should the nurse take to maintain asepsis?
options: Scrub the tubing port with an alcohol swab
Obtain a new IV solution bag
Obtain new IV tubing
Wipe the tubing port with povidone-iodine solution
questions.rationale: If IV tubing becomes contaminated as a result of coming into contact with some nonsterile object, sterile technique is broken and new IV tubing should be obtained. The IV solution bag has not been contaminated and does not need replacement.

questions.stem: A home health nurse is visiting a client with tuberculosis (TB). Which action by the client tells the nurse that the client understands the necessary respiratory precautions to be taken at home?
options: Wearing an oxygen mask at all times
Staying secluded in the bedroom
Disposing of contaminated tissues in a container with a leak-proof bag
Keeping the house closed up to minimize the spread of disease
questions.rationale: The client under respiratory precautions at home does not need to remain secluded. The house should be properly ventilated, and the windows should be opened as much as possible. Contaminated tissues should be discarded in a container with a leak-proof bag.

questions.stem: A nurse caring for a client who is under airborne precautions notes that the client is scheduled for a nuclear scan. Which action on the part of the nurse is appropriate?
options: Planning to have the nuclear scan performed at the bedside
Asking the technicians in the nuclear scan department to wear masks
Calling the nuclear medicine department and telling the technician that the test will have to be delayed until airborne precautions have been discontinued
Placing a surgical mask on the client for transport and for contact with other individuals
questions.rationale: If the client is under airborne precautions, client movement and transport should be limited as much as possible. If transport or movement is necessary, the nurse must place a surgical mask on the client. Having the scan performed at the bedside is unreasonable.

questions.stem: A nurse employed in a physician's office hears a client in the waiting room call out, "Help! Fire!" The nurse rushes to the waiting room and finds that the wastebasket is on fire. What should the nurse immediately do?
options: Remove the clients from the waiting room
Confine the fire
Extinguish the fire
Activate the fire alarm
questions.rationale: The nurse should immediately remove any clients in immediate danger. The next step is to activate the fire alarm. The nurse would then confine the fire by closing all the doors and, finally, extinguish the fire.

questions.stem: A nurse enters the laundry room to empty a bag of dirty linen and discovers a fire in a laundry basket. What action should the nurse take first?
options: Extinguishing the fire
Confining the fire
Activating the fire alarm
Running for the fire extinguisher
questions.rationale: The first priority in the event of a fire is rescuing the clients in immediate danger. In this situation, no clients are in immediate danger. The next step is to activate the fire alarm. The nurse then confines the fire by closing all doors and, finally, extinguishes the fire.

questions.stem: The safety department is providing a yearly educational session on fire safety and the use of fire extinguishers. A nurse is asked to demonstrate the use of a fire extinguisher after the session. What does the nurse do first when demonstrating appropriate use of the fire extinguisher?
options: Squeezing the handle of the extinguisher
Sweeping from the top to the bottom of the fire with the extinguisher
Pulling the pin on the fire extinguisher
Aiming at the base of the fire
questions.rationale: To use a fire extinguisher, pull the pin first. Next, aim the extinguisher at the base of the fire. Squeeze the handle of the extinguisher, then extinguish the fire by sweeping from side to side. Use the mnemonic PASS: Pull the pin, aim at the base of the fire, squeeze the handle, and sweep.

questions.stem: A nurse provides instruction to a new nursing assistant regarding the application of a restraint to a client. The nurse watches as the nursing assistant applies the restraint. What observation tells the nurse that the nursing assistant is using correct procedure?
options: The assistant secures the restraint in such a way that it is impossible to slip a finger between the restraint and the client's skin.
The assistant applies a tie knot in the restraint strap.
The assistant attaches the restraint straps securely to the side rails.
The assistant applies the restraint so that the strap does not tighten when force is applied against it.
questions.rationale: A half bow or safety knot should be used to apply a restraint, because it does not tighten when force is applied against it and because the person can quickly release the client in an emergency. The restraint strap is secured to the bed frame, never to the side rails.

questions.stem: A home care nurse visits a client who lives in a small apartment to perform an admission assessment. During the home safety assessment, the client asks the nurse whether it is safe to use a space heater. What is the appropriate response by the nurse?
options: "A space heater should never be used in an apartment."
"A space heater can be used as long as it is kept in the bedroom at night in case a fire occurs."
"A space heater can be used as long as it is kept at a low setting at all times."
"A space heater can be used as long as it's placed at least 3 feet (1 meter) from anything that may ignite."
questions.rationale: Space heaters must be used appropriately because of the risk of fire. A space heater should be placed at least 3 feet (1 meter) from anything that may ignite. A space heater may be used in an apartment if these precautions are taken.

questions.stem: A nurse is preparing to initiate a continuous tube feeding, using a tube-feeding pump. On bringing the pump to the bedside and preparing to plug the pump in, the nurse discovers that there is no available plug in the wall socket. What is the most appropriate action the nurse should do?
options: Ask the primary health care provider to change the prescription to intermittent feedings
Plug in the pump cord into an available plug above the sink
Determine the need for the appliances now plugged into the needed wall socket
Use a regular extension cord to allow the use of more than one electrical appliance
questions.rationale: It is most appropriate for the nurse to assess the situation and determine the need for the appliances already plugged into the needed wall socket. A regular extension cord should not be used because it poses a risk of fire.

questions.stem: A licensed practical nurse (LPN) tells the registered nurse (RN) that the administered acetaminophen to a client by way of the rectal route rather than the prescribed oral route because the client was extremely nauseous. What is the most appropriate action by the RN?
options: Tells the LPN that she made a sound judgment in administering the medication by way of the rectal route
Instructs the LPN to write "pr" (per rectum) on the medication record next to the time at which the medication was administered
Asks the LPN to check the client in 30 minutes to see whether the nausea has subsided
Asks the LPN to complete and file an incident report
questions.rationale: If a medication is prescribed to be administered by way of the oral route, the nurse may not use the rectal route to administer the medication unless the change is prescribed by the primary health care provider. The nurse would ask the LPN to complete and file an incident report because the LPN made a medication error.

questions.stem: A nurse receives a telephone call from the admissions office and is told that a client scheduled for an internal radiation implant will be admitted to the nursing unit. Which of the following precautions does the nurse include in the client's plan of care?
options: Wearing gloves when emptying the client's bedpan
Placing used linen in double bags and sending a bag to the laundry room every evening
Allowing the client to ambulate in the hall only once a day
Placing the client in a semi-private room at the end of a hallway
questions.rationale: A primary goal of care for the client with an internal radiation implant is to prevent exposure to radiation. A client with an internal radiation implant is required to remain in a private room to prevent accidental exposure. The nurse should wear gloves when emptying the client's bedpan.

questions.stem: A nursing instructor is observing a nursing student who is practicing the use of standard precautions in the nursing laboratory. Which of the following observations by the instructor indicates a need for further teaching?
options: The nursing student washes her hands before glove removal after emptying a Foley bag.
The nursing student washes hands before making contact with the client.
The nursing student changes gloves between tasks and procedures.
The nursing student wears a gown to change the bed of an incontinent client.
questions.rationale: Standard precautions require that gloves be removed promptly after use and before the wearer touches noncontaminated surfaces or other clients. If proper care with gloves, hands, and after each glove removal after emptying a Foley bag is essential to the principles of standard precautions.

questions.stem: A home care nurse is instructing a client in the use of ice packs to treat an eye injury. What does the nurse instruct the client to do?
options: Wrap a plastic bag filled with ice in a pillowcase and place it on the eye
Avoid the use of commercially prepared ice bags
Place the ice pack directly on the eye
Keep the ice pack on the eye continuously for 24 hours
questions.rationale: An ice pack placed directly against the skin or left in place for an extended period carries a risk of tissue damage. To help prevent tissue damage resulting from excessive cold exposure, the ice pack should be wrapped in a pillowcase or towel.

questions.stem: The unit supervisor of an emergency department (ED) is called at home and told by an emergency department nurse who is on duty that an airplane crash has occurred and numerous casualties will be arriving at the ED. What should the initial response by the unit supervisor be?
options: "Has the disaster plan been activated?"
"Be sure that the nursing staff finds as many stretchers as they can."
"Call as many nursing staff as you can to come in to work."
"Make sure all of the rooms are well stocked with supplies."
questions.rationale: In an external disaster, many people will be brought to the ED for treatment. The initial nursing action must be activation of the disaster plan. Although ensuring that rooms are well stocked with supplies and calling nursing staff to come to work are components of preparing for casualties, these should be done after the disaster plan has been activated.

questions.stem: A community health nurse is providing an educational session on childhood poisoning at a local school. What does the nurse tell the group what the first action is when an accidental poisoning occurs?
options: Induce vomiting
Bring the child to the emergency department (ED)
Call an ambulance
Call the poison control center
questions.rationale: When a poisoning occurs, a poison control center should be contacted immediately and given specific treatment. Vomiting should not be induced if the victim is unconscious or if the substance ingested was a strong corrosive or petroleum product.

questions.stem: A nurse is assisting with disaster relief after a tornado. The nurse's goal with the overall community is to prevent as much injury and death resulting from the uncontrollable event as possible. Finding safe housing for survivors, providing support to families, organizing counseling sessions, and securing physical care when needed are all examples of which level of prevention?
options: Secondary
Primary
Initial
Tertiary
questions.rationale: Tertiary prevention involves the reduction of the amount and degree of disability, injury, and damage after a crisis. Tertiary prevention is aimed at reducing the long-term effects of disease or crisis that has already occurred.

questions.stem: A nurse in a post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) receives a client from the operating room. For what finding should the PACU nurse assess the client first?
options: Airway patency
Active bowel sounds
Orientation to surroundings
Adequate urine output
questions.rationale: After a client's transfer from the operating room, the PACU nurse performs an assessment, assessing airway patency first. The client may not have active bowel sounds at this time as a result of the effects of anesthesia.

questions.stem: A staff nurse caring for a client with a head injury notes that the client is restless and pulling at the intravenous (IV) line. The client's primary health care provider does not want to prescribe sedation, and the family has requested that the client not be restrained. Which action by the nurse is best?
options: Asking a family member to sit with the client
Telling the family that the application of wrist restraints is critical in preventing injury to the client
Asking a nursing assistant to monitor the client
Staying with the client and consulting with the nurse manager about the situation
questions.rationale: The nurse must stay with the client and consult with the nurse manager about the situation. It may be necessary for the nurse manager to call the supervisor to request an additional staff member to be assigned to stay with the client. Application of restraints may agitate the client, causing further recklessness.

questions.stem: A nurse manager of an emergency department (ED) arrives at work and is told that four registered nurses called in sick and will not be reporting to work because they are ill. Every trauma room is busy, and emergency medical services (EMS) has just called to report that several victims involved in a 10-car wreck on the interstate will be brought to the ED. How does the nurse manager initially manage this situation?
options: Calling the nursing supervisor to discuss activation of the disaster plan
Closing the emergency department temporarily to incoming clients
Demanding that the nurses from the night shift stay until all of the victims have been treated
Telling EMS to take the victims to another hospital
questions.rationale: External disasters occur in the community, and many victims of such events are brought to the ED for care. The nurse manager would initially call the nursing supervisor to discuss the additional staffing needs and the development of the disaster plan.

questions.stem: A nurse responds to an external disaster that occurred in a large city when a building collapsed. Numerous victims require treatment. Which victim should the nurse attend to first?
options: An alert victim who has numerous bruises on the arms and legs
A victim with a partial amputation of a leg who is bleeding profusely
A hysterical victim who has sustained a head injury
A victim who has died of multiple serious injuries
questions.rationale: The nurse determines which victim will be attended to first on the basis of the severity of injury. A victim with a partial amputation who is bleeding profusely requires immediate attention. Immediate attention is categorized as emergent, and this is the priority in this case.

questions.stem: A nurse giving a client a bed bath drops the towel on the floor. What should the nurse do?
options: Borrow a towel from the client's roommate
Use a bath blanket as a towel
Wash his/her hands and go to the linen room to obtain another towel
Wash his/her hands, pick up the towel, and shake the towel out
questions.rationale: To avoid spreading the client's germs, the nurse must wash her hands before leaving the client's room. Therefore the nurse should cover the client and ensure that the client is safe, wash her hands, and go to the linen room to obtain another towel. It is never appropriate to borrow other clients' supplies.

questions.stem: A nurse manager tells the nursing staff that the agency's disaster preparedness plan will be distributed to all employees for review. What does the nurse manager say is a primary component of disaster readiness?
options: Identify the types of disasters that may occur
Identify the location of healthcare supplies
Describe a formal plan of action for the coordination of a response
Aid determination of how victims will be triaged
questions.rationale: A primary component of a disaster preparedness plan is a formal plan of action for coordination of a response of a healthcare agency. Depending on the agency, the disaster preparedness plan may be specific and may include other information such as the location of health care supplies and the types of disasters.

questions.stem: A home health nurse is performing an assessment of a client's skin. The nurse, noting multiple thread-like lines, both straight and wavy, beneath the skin, recognizes the presence of scabies. Which of the following precautions should the nurse institute before completing the assessment of the client?
options: Avoiding sitting on the client's furniture
Putting on a gown and gloves
Putting on a pair of gloves
Donning a mask and gloves
questions.rationale: Scabies is usually transmitted from person to person by way of direct skin contact. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends the wearing of gowns and gloves for close contact with a person infected with scabies.

questions.stem: An industrial nurse at a large factory provides information to the employees in the mailroom and shipping department about the signs of skin (cutaneous) anthrax. For which early sign of cutaneous anthrax does the nurse tell the employees to check their skin?
options: A weeping blister
A black skin area of skin
An itchy lump
An open ulcer
questions.rationale: Skin anthrax starts with an itchy lump (papule) that looks like a mosquito bite. It progresses to a small fluid-filled sac that becomes a painless ulcer with an area of dead black tissue in the middle.

questions.stem: A nurse educator is providing an in-service program to emergency department nurses about the signs/symptoms of inhalation anthrax. What does the nurse educator tell the nurses is an early indication of inhalation anthrax?
options: Signs/symptoms of shock
Respiratory distress
Flulike signs/symptoms
Hemorrhage
questions.rationale: Inhalation anthrax is caused by the inhalation of spores from Bacillus anthracis. This form of anthrax begins with flulike signs/symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and fatigue. Signs/symptoms suddenly become more severe with the development of breathing problems and chest pain.

questions.stem: A post office employee with suspected skin anthrax asks the emergency department nurse whether the infection is curable. What is the appropriate response by the nurse?
options: "That's hard to say. We won't know for a week or two."
"You really need to ask your primary health care provider."
"Antibiotic therapy is usually prescribed and will cure the infection."
"It is not curable, but fortunately, unlike inhalation anthrax, it is not deadly."
questions.rationale: Skin anthrax is curable with antibiotic therapy. Antibiotic therapy usually cures the infection, but untreated skin anthrax can result in overwhelming septicemia and death.

questions.stem: A military nurse who is in charge of planning a vaccination clinic to administer the smallpox vaccine to military personnel is preparing a pamphlet that sets forth guidelines for care of the vaccination site. Which guideline should the nurse include in the pamphlet?
options: Apply an antihistamine ointment to the scab to prevent itching.
Keep the vaccination site open to air as much as possible.
Avoid sharing towels or other items that have come in contact with the vaccination site.
Soak the scab that forms with warm water every day.
questions.rationale: A scab will form in the spot where the vaccination was administered. This scab should be left alone so that the vaccinia virus doesn't spread to other parts of the body. The vaccine is told to avoid sharing towels and to launder items that have touched the vaccination site.

questions.stem: A nurse in a long-term care facility recognizes the need to place wrist restraints on a client, but the client does not want the restraints applied. What would be the most appropriate action by the nurse?
options: Medicate the client with a sedative, then apply the restraints
Apply the restraints anyway
Contact the primary health care provider
Compromise with the client and use only one wrist restraint instead of two
questions.rationale: The use of restraints must be avoided if possible. If it is determined that a restraint is necessary, the nurse should discuss this with the client and obtain a prescription from the primary health care provider. The nurse should explain carefully to the client and family the reason that the restraint is necessary.

questions.stem: A nurse caring for a 9-month-old who has undergone repair of a cleft palate applies elbow restraints to the child. The mother visits her child and asks the nurse to remove the restraints. According to the guidelines for the use of restraints, what should the nurse do in response to the mother's request?
options: Remove a restraint from one extremity
Tell the mother that the restraints may not be removed
Remove both restraints
Loosen the restraints after telling the mother that they may not be removed
questions.rationale: Elbow restraints are used after cleft palate repair to prevent the child from touching the repair site. The restraints may be removed one at a time only to assess or permit the child to play with or help with range-of-motion exercises.

questions.stem: A nurse is admitting a postoperative client from the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) to the surgical nursing unit. Which of the following measures should the nurse take for the safety of the client?
options: Putting the side rails up all removing the client from the stretcher
Quickly moving the client from the stretcher to the bed
Uncovering the client before making the transfer from the stretcher to the bed
Asking the client to slide from the stretcher to the bed
questions.rationale: Because the client may be experiencing residual effects of anesthesia, the nurse should raise the side rails up all removing the client from the stretcher to the bed. The nurse should avoid opening the postoperative client during transfer because of the potential for heat loss.

questions.stem: A client with a new diagnosis of tuberculosis (TB) is being admitted to the hospital. During the collection of data from the client, which of the following considerations is most important?
options: The name of the person from whom the client contracted TB, so that the person may be reported for follow-up care
What medications have been prescribed and what the client knows about his or her side effects
The religious affiliation or church of preference
The names of close friends and family members
questions.rationale: TB is a contagious disease that is spread in respiratory droplets. The nurse needs to elicit the names of close friends and family members because all suspected persons should be contacted and should have exposure to TB.

questions.stem: A client with osteoporosis is at risk for falls. Which statement by the client indicates the need for instruction regarding measures to prevent falls?
options: "I use a shower chair when I bathe."
"The railings on my stairs are sturdy and secure."
"I've placed nightlights in my hallway."
"I took the bathmat out of my tub."
questions.rationale: Home modifications to reduce the risk of falls include use of sturdy, secure railings on all staircases and ample lighting, including nightlights. Bathroom safety equipment includes a shower chair. Removing bath mats is appropriate to prevent falls.

questions.stem: An adolescent client asks the nurse questions about the transmission of Epstein-Barr virus (infectious mononucleosis). By which route should the nurse tell the client that the disease is transmitted?
options: Respiratory droplets
Close intimate contact
Airborne particles
Fecal-oral
questions.rationale: Epstein-Barr virus is transmitted by way of contact with infectious saliva. Close intimate contact with an infected person is necessary. The virus is commonly shed from before clinical onset until 6 months or longer after recovery.

questions.stem: A teenage client returns to the gynecological (GYN) clinic for a follow-up visit after diagnosis and initial treatment of a sexually transmitted infection (STI). Which statement by the client indicates the need for further teaching?
options: "I know you won't tell my parents I'm in sick."
"I always make sure my boyfriend uses a condom."
"My boyfriend doesn't have to come in for treatment."
"I finished all the antibiotic, just like you said."
questions.rationale: In the treatment of STIs, all sexual contacts must be alerted and treated with appropriate medication. Any client who is being treated for an STI should also use a condom for any sexual contact.

questions.stem: A nurse has provided instructions to a mother regarding the use of safety seats in car travel for her newborn infant. Which statement by the mother indicates understanding of the instructions?
options: "I'll put the baby's car seat in the middle back seat, facing backward and reclined a little."
"I'll put the baby's car seat in the middle back seat, facing forward and reclined a little."
"I'll put the baby's car seat in the front seat, facing forward and reclined a little."
"I'll put the baby's car seat in the front seat, facing backward and reclined a little."
questions.rationale: The infant should be restrained in a car seat in a semireclining, rear-facing position to allow the seat and infant's spine to bear the forces of impact should a collision occur. The infant should never be placed in the front seat.

questions.stem: During a laboratory training session, the nurse is watching as a nursing assistant repositions a client. Which observation tells the nurse that further training is necessary?
options: The nursing assistant encourages the client to assist as much as possible.
The nursing assistant keeps his/her neck, back, pelvis, and feet aligned.
The nursing assistant positions himself/herself close to the client.
The nursing assistant keeps his/her knees straight and his/her feet close together.
questions.rationale: To help prevent injury, the nurse needs to use and encourage staff members to use good body mechanics and ergonomic principles in providing care. The nursing assistant should keep his/her knees bent, feet apart, and body close to the client being moved.

questions.stem: A nurse preparing to perform a sterile dressing change notes that the covering of a package of sterile 4 x 4 gauze pads has a small tear. Which action should the nurse take?
options: Examine the gauze pads and using them as long as they appear untouched
Discard the gauze pad closest to the outside of the package and using the others
Discard the package
Use the gauze pads, because the tear was small
questions.rationale: When performing a surgically aseptic procedure, if the integrity of a sterile object becomes questionable (e.g., if there is a tear or break in the covering), the nurse must discard the object, because it is considered contaminated.

questions.stem: A sedated client is being transported to the radiology department on a stretcher. Which type of restraint should the nurse suggest applying to help ensure the client's safety?
options: Wrist
Mitten
Elbow
Belt
questions.rationale: A belt restraint is a device that is wrapped around the client's waist to secure the client to a bed or to a stretcher. An elbow restraint consists of a piece of fabric with slots into which tongue blades are inserted. A mitten restraint is a thumbless device that covers the client's hand. A wrist restraint is a device used to immobilize an arm that does not allow movement as a mitten restraint.

questions.stem: A hospitalized client, experiencing confusion, is at risk of falling because she continually tries to climb out of bed. Which of these safety devices that the nurse might suggest is the least restrictive?
options: Ambularm
Elbow
Belt
Wrist
questions.rationale: The Ambularm device, worn on the leg, signals when the client's leg is in a dependent position. It is used for clients who may be at risk for falling. It does not restrict the client's ability to assist in mobilizing that may be attached to the bed or chair. A wrist restraint is used to immobilize an arm. An elbow restraint consists of a piece of fabric with slots into which tongue blades are inserted, the Ambularm is the least restrictive safety device.

questions.stem: A nurse is performing sterile wound irrigation for an assigned client. A nursing assistant enters the client's room and tells the nurse that a primary health care provider has telephoned and has asked to speak to the nurse. What is the appropriate action by the nurse?
options: Asking the nursing assistant to take a message
Covering the client and answering the telephone call
Finishing the wound irrigation while the primary health care provider waits on the telephone
Asking the nursing assistant to obtain a telephone number from the primary health care provider so that the nurse may return the call after the wound irrigation is complete
questions.rationale: Because wound irrigation is a sterile procedure and a risk for infection exists with any open wound, the nurse should ask the nursing assistant to obtain a telephone number so that the call may be returned after the wound irrigation is complete. It is best to return the call after the procedure is being completed. It is best to return the call after the wound irrigation is complete.

questions.stem: A registered nurse (RN) is watching as a new licensed practical nurse (LPN) suctions a client with a diagnosis of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Which of the following protective devices worn by the LPN would cause the RN to determine that the LPN was performing the procedure safely?
options: Gloves, gown, and face shield
Gown and protective eyewear
Gloves and mask
Gloves and gown
questions.rationale: The RN is responsible for supervising procedures performed by a new LPN to ensure that safety is maintained and that policies and procedure guidelines are followed. Standard precautions include the use of gloves, gown, and face shield. The LPN also needs to protect the eyes, nose, and mouth from contact with the client's respiratory secretions.

questions.stem: A home health nurse has instructed a client about safety measures during the use of an oxygen concentrator in the home. Which statement by the client indicates to the nurse that the client understands the directions? Select all that apply.
options: "I need to place the oxygen concentrator as close to the wall as possible or put it in a corner."
"I need to follow the oxygen prescription exactly."
"I have to tell everyone that they can't smoke or have an open flame within 10 feet (3 meters) of the oxygen concentrator."
"I can use my electric razor while I'm using oxygen."
"I should keep the oxygen concentrator out of direct sunlight."
questions.rationale: The client should follow the oxygen prescription exactly. The use of electric razors or other equipment that could emit sparks should be avoided while oxygen is in use, because fire and ignition sources could result from heat in the form of flames or sparks. The oxygen concentrator should be placed slightly away from walls and corners to permit adequate air flow. Smoking should never be allowed within 10 feet (3 meters) of the oxygen concentrator.

questions.stem: A community health nurse is providing information to local residents about the transmission of anthrax. Through which body systems does the nurse tell the residents that anthrax can be contracted? Select all that apply.
options: Lymphatic
Respiratory (Lungs)
Integumentary System (Skin)
Gastrointestinal
Urinary
Immune
questions.rationale: Anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, can be contracted through the respiratory system (inhalation), the gastrointestinal system, and the integumentary system (skin). It is not contracted through the immune system, urinary tract, or lymphatic system.

questions.stem: A home health nurse teaches a client about home modifications to reduce the risk of falls. Which statements by the client indicate a need for further teaching? Select all that apply.
options: "I need to use night lights."
"I need to use the staircase handrails when I go up the stairs."
"I need to remove my wall-to-wall carpeting."
"I should walk barefoot as much as possible so that I'll know about any wet spots on the floor."
"I need to get handrails put up in the bathroom."
questions.rationale: Home modifications to reduce the risk of falls include ensuring ample lighting, removing scatter rugs, securing loose handrails in bathrooms, and wearing sturdy flat rubber-soled shoes to prevent slips and falls. Walking barefoot will not reduce the risk of falls. Removal of wall-to-wall carpeting is not necessary.

questions.stem: A registered nurse is instructing a group of nursing assistants in the principles of body mechanics. Which of these observations tell the nurse that a student is using the principles appropriately? Select all that apply.
options: The assistant positions a box that is to be lifted between his knees.
The assistant's hips a client requiring total care into a chair without additional assistance.
The assistant turns his back to change position while moving a client.
The assistant leans forward when turning a client in bed.
The assistant keeps the object to be moved as close to his body as possible.
questions.rationale: When moving an object, the nursing assistant should position the object between his knees. The assistant should keep the client or object to be moved as close to his body as possible. When turning a client, the assistant should not turn his back to change position while moving a client. The assistant should turn his feet, rather than twisting his back.

questions.stem: A physician writes a prescription for the application of a heating pad to a client's back. Which of the following actions should the nurse take when implementing this prescription? Select all that apply.
options: Assessing the client's medical history and risk factors for burns
Adjusting the heating pad to the high setting
Assessing the heating pad periodically for proper electrical function
Placing the heating pad under the client
Frequently assessing the client's skin for signs of burns
questions.rationale: The nurse should first assess the client's medical history, including risk factors for burns. The heating pad should not be placed under the client as this could result in burns from the direct heat. Assessing the client for proper electrical function is an appropriate measure for safe use of a heating pad. Frequently assessing the client's skin for signs of burns is important.

questions.stem: A fever develops in a client who has been hospitalized for 2 months and is receiving parenteral nutrition by way of a central venous line, and central venous line-related sepsis is diagnosed. What does the nurse interpret the meaning of this infection? Select all that apply.
options: A hospital-acquired infection
A healthcare-associated infection
A nosocomial infection
A community-acquired infection
An iatrogenic infection
A result of bacterial colonization
questions.rationale: Infections that occur during hospitalization, or are a result of hospitalization, are referred to as healthcare-associated infections, hospital-acquired infections, or nosocomial infections. Colonization is defined as a condition in which microorganisms are present in body tissues; there is no damage to the tissues, and no local signs/symptoms of infection are evident.

questions.stem: A nurse educator is providing in-service sessions to the nursing staff regarding employee safety and the prevention of occupationally acquired HIV infection. Which of the following precautions does the nurse instruct the nursing staff to take as a means of preventing accidental needlesticks? Select all that apply.
options: The use of needleless devices
Disposal of needles in special puncture-resistant containers
The use of latex gloves
The use of shielded needles
The use of recessed needles
questions.rationale: Although strict adherence to universal or standard precautions can reduce significantly the incidence of exposure to blood and body fluids, the use of recessed needles, needleless devices, shielded needles, and puncture-resistant containers for the disposal of needles are all of significant benefit in the disposal of accidental needlesticks.

questions.stem: A nurse is preparing to clean up a blood spill on the client's bedside table that occurred when a blood tube containing a specimen from the client broke. What steps should the nurse take to clean up the blood spill? Select all that apply.
options: Using tongs to collect any broken glass
Placing the pieces of broken glass in a plastic bag
Disinfecting the area of the blood spill with a dilute bleach solution
Blotting up the spill with a face cloth or cloth towel
Wearing gloves for the cleanup procedure
questions.rationale: The nurse should blot the spill with an absorbent disposable material such as disposable towels, not a face cloth or cloth towel. The broken glass is disposed of in a sharps container. The area is disinfected with a dilute Bleach solution or other agency-accepted product.

questions.stem: A client undergoing chemotherapy is found to have an extremely low white blood cell count, and neutropenic precautions, including a low-bacteria diet, are immediately instituted. Which of these food items will the client be allowed to consume? Select all that apply.
options: Well-cooked cheeseburger
Tossed salad
Italian bread
Raw celery
Fresh apple
Baked chicken
questions.rationale: An extremely low white blood cell count puts the client at risk for infection, necessitating the implementation of a low-bacteria diet. The client must avoid fresh fruits and vegetables, which may harbor microorganisms that cause infection, and ensure that meat is thoroughly cooked. Italian bread, baked chicken, and a well-done cheeseburger are all acceptable foods for the diet.

questions.stem: Which actions should the nurse take in the event of an accidental poisoning? Select all that apply.
options: Removing any visible materials from the nose and mouth
Determining the type and amount of substance ingested
Inducing vomiting if a household cleaner has been ingested
Saving vomitus for laboratory analysis
Assessing the client's airway patency, breathing, and circulation
questions.rationale: In the event of accidental poisoning, the poison center is called before any attempt at interventions is made. Additional interventions in an accidental poisoning include assessing the client's airway patency, breathing, and circulation; removing any visible materials from the nose and mouth to terminate exposure; determining the type and amount of substance ingested, if possible; and saving vomitus for laboratory analysis. Vomiting should never be induced in an unconscious client or if the substance is incompatible with vomiting is never induced in an unconscious client or if the substance is a strong corrosive or petroleum product.

questions.stem: A nurse is assigned to care for a client with an infection caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The client has an abdominal wound that requires irrigation and has a tracheostomy attached to a mechanical ventilator that requires frequent suctioning. While gathering the needed supplies before entering the client's room, which necessary protective items does the nurse obtain? Select all that apply.
options: Gown
Face shield
Gloves
Mask
Shoe protectors
questions.rationale: Infection caused by MRSA necessitates contact precautions. The care of this client requires the use of gown, gloves, and a face shield. The face shield is worn to protect the face and the mucous membranes of the mouth, nose, and eyes during interventions that could produce splashes of blood, body fluids, secretions, and excretions. Masks do not provide adequate protection. Shoe protectors are not necessary.

questions.stem: A nurse is attending an in-service program on disaster preparedness. Which of the following events are described as examples of natural disasters? Select all that apply.
options: Hurricane
Terrorist attack
Toxic waste spill
Drought
Bus accident
Flood
questions.rationale: A disaster is any human-made or natural event that results in destruction and devastation that cannot be alleviated without outside assistance. A natural disaster usually cannot be prevented, whereas a human-made disaster can be prevented. Flood, drought, and hurricane are the only natural disasters identified in the options. Bus accidents, terrorist attacks, and toxic waste spills are all human-made disasters.

questions.stem: A nurse is reading an article about the role of the American Red Cross (ARC) in a disaster. Which of the following responsibilities does the article ascribe to the ARC? Select all that apply.
options: Identifying and training personnel for disaster response
Developing a federal disaster response plan
Educating the public about ways to prepare for disasters
Declaring a disaster
Providing disaster relief
Activating disaster medical assistant teams
questions.rationale: The ARC has been given authority by the federal government to provide disaster relief. The organization works with the government in developing and testing community disaster plans, identifying and training personnel for disaster response, working with businesses and labor organizations to identify resources and people for disaster relief, educating the public about ways to prepare for disasters, and other responsibilities. Other responsibilities include operating shelters, providing disaster relief services in mass care, and providing relief-related information.

questions.stem: A nurse leading an educational session about terrorism for members of the community is discussing anthrax. Which of the following pieces of information should the nurse provide to the group attending the session? Select all that apply.
options: Anthrax can be transmitted from person to person.
One way that anthrax can be contracted is through the skin.
Anthrax is never fatal.
A blood test is available for the detection of anthrax.
No vaccine to prevent anthrax is available.
questions.rationale: Anthrax, which is caused by Bacillus anthracis, can be contracted through the digestive system (foodborne), the skin (cutaneous), the lungs (inhalation anthrax), or through contact with infectious saliva. Close intimate contact with an infected person should be treated for scabies at the same time. A blood test performed to detect anthrax includes antibodies or DNA from the anthrax. A vaccine exists, but its availability is limited. Anthrax is usually treated with ciprofloxacin, doxycycline, or penicillin.

questions.stem: According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) description of the phases of disaster management, what are the three components of actions in the mitigation phase? Select all that apply.
options: Determining available resources for the care of infants, older clients, the disabled, and people with chronic health problems
Actions that can prevent the occurrence of a disaster
Measures that can reduce a disaster's damaging effects
Putting disaster planning services into action
Actions taken to return to normal after the disaster
Actions that plan for rescue, evacuation, and care of disaster victims
